feed.title: Combined summary - Bootstrapping via BitTorrent trackers

entry.title: Combined summary - Bootstrapping via BitTorrent trackers
entry.summary: The discussion in this context is about the bootstrapping mechanisms used for starting up nodes in the Bitcoin network. Currently, there are several options such as IRC bootstrapping, hardcoded/fallback nodes, and DNS seeding. However, these methods have limitations and concerns such as being overly complex, vulnerable to Sybil attacks, and prone to poisoned seeds.One proposed solution is BitTorrent tracker bootstrapping which would be a simpler and more efficient method of returning a list of nodes with the same hash given a SHA1 hash. While Jeff Garzik expressed concerns about potential vulnerabilities with BitTorrent tracker bootstrapping and the possibility of Sybil attacks on DHTs, Christian Decker suggested using HTTP requests for a tracker over keeping an IRC connection open at all times.Another proposed solution is DNS bootstrapping which can be very robust by hosting seeds with services like zerigo and thousands of small VPS operated by people all over the world. Gavin suggested improving DNS bootstrapping by publishing build instructions for a simple DNS server and a script that feeds it with node data. Hardcoding a bunch of such DNS seeds into the client and adding the code to Bitcoin in a contrib/dns folder would simplify the process.In addition, Vladimir Marchenko proposed a bootstrap method in which bitcoind would listen on a specific last octet of an IPv4 address, such as .14. However, this method was deemed impractical and messy by other members of the discussion. Jeff Garzik also raised concerns about how clients would discover HTTP trackers and suggested looking at the history and experience of gnutella's web caches vs. UDP host caches.Using HTTP requests to a tracker has several benefits such as better load balancing, no virus/botnet like behavior, and faster adaptation than DNS Seeds. Christian Decker suggested using BitTorrent tracker bootstrapping as an alternative to IRC bootstrapping and hardcoded nodes. He believes that using trackers such as OpenBittorrent would provide the same advantages as using an IRC channel, making it harder for attackers to get bootstrapping clients to connect exclusively to their compromised clients. Jeff Garzik, on the other hand, argues that BitTorrent tracker bootstrapping offers few benefits over DNS seeding and could potentially create a vulnerable hot spot in the DHT due to Sybil attacks.In June 2011, Gavin suggested a practical way to improve DNS bootstrapping by publishing build instructions for a simple DNS server and a script that feeds it with node data. He proposed using something like djbdns plus a Perl script or similar zerigo API script. The idea was to hardcode a bunch of such DNS seeds into the client. Jeff Garzik agreed that adding this code to Bitcoin in a contrib/dns folder would be a good idea. He planned to put together a couple of different solutions within three to four weeks.Jeff had a thought related to this. He suggested creating an RPC in Bitcoin that returns a random selection of fresh P2P node addresses from addr.dat. He ran into trouble accessing this data from outside Bitcoin and thought that ArtForz's half-a-node could be used as a base. However, he believed creating a "getnodes" RPC would be far easier. Jeff recommended using djbdns (tinydns) as it is highly scalable and stable, and its input is a very simple text format, easier to generate than BIND zone files. Gavin expressed his willingness to run a DNS seed. Jeff emphasized the importance of trusted people running DNS seeds on stable connectivity once the DNS software is there.
